questions.text: A 5-month-old baby has developmental delay, and the blood work shows megaloblastic anaemia, though B12 and folate are in the higher range. Urinalysis shows formation of a crystalline substance upon standing. Supplementation of the child’s diet with uridine reversed all the clinical symptoms. The crystalline substance is composed of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Orotate

 

The child is diagnosed to have hereditary orotic aciduria, which is due to a mutation in UMP synthase → leads to orotic acid accumulation in the urine.

 

On treatment with uridine, the block is bypassed and allows UTP, CTP and dTTP synthesis.

 

Uridine treatment has the beneficial effect of blocking.

 

Explanaton:

 

Option A. Uracil - While uracil is a pyrimidine base, the clinical scenario specifically points to the accumulation of orotate, a precursor in the pyrimidine synthesis pathway, not uracil itself.

 

Option B. Thymine - Thymine is another pyrimidine base found in DNA, but the condition described does not lead to thymine accumulation.

 

Option D. Aspartate - Aspartate is an amino acid involved in various metabolic processes, including the urea cycle and nucleotide synthesis, but it is not the crystalline substance described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hereditary orotic aciduria, a rare autosomal recessive disorder, characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme UMP synthase, crucial for the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine nucleotides. The deficiency leads to an accumulation of orotic acid, which is excreted in the urine and can crystallize.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 587.

questions.text: During pyrimidine nucleotide synthesis, one of the amino acids donates a nitrogen atom to form the pyrimidine ring. Which amino acid contributes the nitrogen at the N1 position in this structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aspartate

 

Option A.

 

Aspartate provides the nitrogen atom at the N1 position of the pyrimidine ring in the synthesis of pyrimidine nucleotides. This occurs in the reaction catalyzed by the enzyme aspartate transcarbamoylase, where aspartate and carbamoyl phosphate combine to form carbamoyl aspartate.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Glutamine: Glutamine donates nitrogen atoms during purine nucleotide synthesis, not for the N1 position of pyrimidines.

 

Option C. Glycine: Glycine contributes to the purine nucleotide structure, not the pyrimidine.

 

Option D. Alanine: Alanine does not contribute nitrogen atoms to the pyrimidine ring structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CONTRIBUTORS OF PYRIMIDINE RING: 

 

  • N3 by Amide Nitrogen of Glutamine
  • C2 by CO2
  • C4, C5, C6, N1 by Aspartate  

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 347-348.

questions.text: An evaluating patients with potential metabolic disorders, identifying conditions that are less likely to present with hyperuricemia is crucial for differential diagnosis. Which of the following conditions would make the presence of hyperuricemia very unlikely in a patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase deficiency

 

Option D.

 

Carbamoyl phosphate (CAP) synthase I is found in mitochondrial matrix and is the first step in urea synthesis, condensing CO2 and NH4+.

 

Hyperammonemia occurs when CAP is deficient.

 

CAP synthase II forms CAP as the first step in pyrimidine synthesis and its complete deficiency would probably be a lethal mutation and when its activity is decreased, purine catabolism to uric acid is decreased, decreasing the possibility of hyperuricemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: This condition is characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme HPRT and is associated with hyperuricemia due to the accumulation of uric acid.

 

Option B. Gout: Gout is directly associated with hyperuricemia, as it is caused by the deposition of urate crystals in joints due to elevated levels of uric acid in the blood.

 

Option C. Xanthine oxidase hyperactivity: Increased activity of xanthine oxidase would lead to increased conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid, potentially resulting in hyperuricemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase (CPS) deficiency is a urea cycle disorder that results in an inability to convert ammonia into urea, leading to hyperammonemia.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 272,511.

questions.text: Which of the following is the rate-controlling step of pyrimidine synthesis which exhibits allosteric inhibition by cytidine triphosphate (CTP)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aspartate transcarbamoylase

 

Option A.

 

It catalyses the first reaction of pyrimidine biosynthesis.

 

This enzyme is inhibited by CTP and activated by ATP.

 

Both ATP and CTP bind at a different site from either substrate.

 

Aspartate transcarbamoylase consists of multiple catalytic and regulatory subunits.

 

Each regulatory subunit contains at least two CTP binding sites

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT): The free purines are salvaged by two different enzymes; adenine phosphoribosyl transferase (APRTase) and hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRTase).

 

Option C. Thymidylate synthase: The methyl group is donated by N5,N10-methylene- THFA. The thymine nucleotide is formed by thymidylate synthase by methylation of dUMP and fluorouracil will inhibit the enzyme, thereby reducing the conversion of dUMP to dTMP.

 

Option D. Ribose-phosphate pyrophosphokinase: In purine biosynthesis, Ribose-5-phosphate + ATP → ADP + Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP), is the donor of ribose-5-phosphate for de novo synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspartate transcarbamoylase (ATCase) is the rate-controlling enzyme of pyrimidine synthesis that is allosterically inhibited by cytidine triphosphate (CTP).

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 586.

choices.text: Addition of nucleotides to RNA during transcription of proviral cDNA
Formation of a phosphodiester bond during viral DNA synthesis
Formation of a peptide bond during translation of viral proteins
Hydrolysis of a phosphodiester bond during viral DNA synthesis

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, recently diagnosed as HIV-positive following exposure from her partner, begins treatment with dideoxycytidine, a nucleoside analog used in antiviral therapy. This medication exerts its effect by interfering with a specific step in the viral replication process. Which of the following best describes the action of dideoxycytidine in inhibiting HIV replication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Formation of a phosphodiester bond during viral DNA synthesis.

 

Explanation:


Dideoxycytidine (ddC), also known as zalcitabine, is a nucleoside analog reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI). It closely resembles cytidine but lacks a 3’-hydroxyl (-OH) group on its deoxyribose sugar.

 

During reverse transcription, HIV reverse transcriptase incorporates ddC into the growing strand of viral DNA. However, the absence of the 3’-OH group means that no new phosphodiester bond can form with the next nucleotide. This causes chain termination, effectively halting DNA synthesis and preventing further viral replication.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Addition of nucleotides to RNA during transcription of proviral cDNA – Incorrect. ddC acts during reverse transcription (RNA → DNA), not during the transcription of DNA to RNA.
  • Option C: Formation of a peptide bond during translation of viral proteins – Incorrect. ddC doesn’t interfere with protein synthesis or translation.
  • Option D: Hydrolysis of a phosphodiester bond during viral DNA synthesis – Incorrect. ddC prevents bond formation; it doesn’t break existing bonds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand how NRTIs like dideoxycytidine act by causing premature chain termination during the reverse transcription step of the HIV life cycle. This directly disrupts viral DNA synthesis and is a key antiviral mechanism.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 7/e: p706.

questions.text: 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) is a widely used chemotherapeutic agent known for its action on nucleotide metabolism pathways. It specifically targets the synthesis of thymidylate (TMP) in pyrimidine biosynthesis, an essential process for DNA replication and cell division. Considering this mechanism, is the following statement accurate: "5-Fluorouracil inhibits the synthesis of TMP in pyrimidine biosynthesis"?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. True

 

Explanation:

 

5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) is a pyrimidine analog that functions as an anticancer drug. It is converted intracellularly to 5-fluoro-dUMP, which inhibits thymidylate synthase, the enzyme responsible for converting dUMP to dTMP (thymidylate).

This inhibition prevents the formation of TMP, which is necessary for DNA synthesis. Without sufficient TMP, DNA replication stalls, particularly affecting rapidly dividing cells like cancer cells. This is why 5-FU is used to treat various solid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand how 5-Fluorouracil targets thymidylate synthase, leading to inhibition of thymidine nucleotide (TMP) synthesis, thus impairing DNA replication in rapidly proliferating cells like tumors.

 

Also know that:

  • Methotrexate indirectly affects TMP synthesis by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), reducing tetrahydrofolate availability for thymidylate synthesis.
  • 5-FU directly inhibits thymidylate synthase, making it a more targeted inhibitor of TMP production.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p717.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b

 

Explanation:

 

1-C: Gout is often caused by defects in purine metabolism, particularly involving PRPP synthetase and HGPRT. Overactivity of PRPP synthetase or deficiency in HGPRT leads to increased production of uric acid, which precipitates in joints causing gouty arthritis.

 

2-D: SCID (Severe Combined Immunodeficiency) can result from a deficiency in ADA (Adenosine Deaminase), which leads to an accumulation of toxic metabolites harmful to lymphocytes, resulting in severe immunodeficiency.

 

3-A: Orotic Aciduria is characterized by megaloblastic anemia and the excretion of large amounts of orotic acid in urine due to a defect in the de novo pyrimidine synthesis pathway, specifically in the enzymes OPRTase and OMP decarboxylase.

 

4-B: Renal lithiasis (Kidney Stones) can occur due to an APRT (Adenine Phosphoribosyltransferase) deficiency, leading to the formation of 2,8-dihydroxyadenine stones, a condition often misdiagnosed as uric acid stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 583.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Urea Cycle Disorder and Orotic Aciduria are interlinked.

 

Reasoning (R): Orotic aciduria occurs in ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency (a urea cycle enzyme) due to the accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate, which then enters the cytosol and serves as a substrate for pyrimidine biosynthesis. Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A as well as R, are right and R is a correct explanation of A

 

Option B.

 

Urea Cycle Disorder and Orotic Aciduria

 

Deficiency in liver mitochondrial enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase → excess carbamoyl phosphate in the mitochondria → which then exits to the cytosol, where it stimulates pyrimidine nucleotide.

 

Orotic aciduria may also occur in ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency (urea cycle enzyme) causes carbamoyl phosphate to accumulate due to defective conversion to citrulline.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urea cycle disorders, such as ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC) deficiency, can lead to the accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate, which can then spill over into the cytosol and be used as a substrate for pyrimidine biosynthesis, resulting in orotic aciduria.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: P 587.

choices.text: Causing cross linkage between adjacent bases of the double helix

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to pain in both lower limbs and a noticeable limp that has persisted for the past three months. After a thorough examination and diagnostic tests, he is diagnosed with osteosarcoma in his right femur. To treat his condition, the oncologist prescribes methotrexate among other antineoplastic drugs as part of his chemotherapy regimen. Given this scenario, what is the mechanism of action of methotrexate in the treatment of osteosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase

 

Option B: 

 

Methotrexate is a structural analog of folic acid that competitively and reversibly inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). This enzyme is essential for converting dihydrofolate (DHF) to tetrahydrofolate (THF). When DHFR is inhibited:

  1. Tetrahydrofolate levels decrease, preventing the formation of one-carbon donors like N5,N10-methylene-THF
  2. Without these methyl donors, thymidylate synthase cannot convert deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP) to deoxythymidine monophosphate (dTMP)
  3. This leads to decreased thymidylate synthesis and subsequent disruption of DNA synthesis
  4. Additionally, purine synthesis is also affected as THF derivatives are required for purine ring formation

 

This mechanism is particularly effective against rapidly dividing cells such as cancer cells in osteosarcoma, which have high requirements for DNA synthesis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Inhibit thymidylate synthase While methotrexate indirectly affects thymidylate synthase function by depleting its cofactor (N5,N10-methylene-THF), it does not directly inhibit this enzyme. Drugs that directly inhibit thymidylate synthase include 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) and raltitrexed.

 

Option C: Availability of AMP is reduced Methotrexate does indirectly affect purine synthesis, which could eventually impact AMP availability. However, this is a secondary effect and not the primary mechanism of action. The reduced availability of THF affects the purine ring formation, but this description is imprecise and incomplete compared to the DHFR inhibition mechanism.

 

Option D: Causing cross linkage between adjacent bases of the double helix This describes the mechanism of action of alkylating agents (such as cyclophosphamide, cisplatin) and some antibiotics (like mitomycin C). These agents form covalent bonds between DNA strands, preventing DNA replication and transcription. Methotrexate does not interact directly with DNA in this manner.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite and antifolate agent that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), leading to depletion of tetrahydrofolate cofactors. This disrupts one-carbon transfer reactions crucial for the synthesis of thymidylate, purines, and certain amino acids (methionine, glycine). The resultant impairment of DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis makes methotrexate effective against rapidly proliferating malignant cells like those in osteosarcoma. 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 514,716,717.

choices.text: Causing cross linkage between adjacent bases of the double helix

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a 6-month history of lower abdominal pain, bloody stools, loss of appetite, and weight loss undergoes a colonoscopy, which reveals a descending colonic mass. A biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma of the colon. Based on the diagnosis, the oncologist decides to prescribe 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) as part of the treatment regimen. Considering the patient's diagnosis and the prescribed medication, what is the mechanism of action of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) as an antineoplastic agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inhibit thymidylate synthase

 

Option A:

 

5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) is a pyrimidine analog structurally similar to uracil and thymine. Inside cells, 5-FU is converted to fluoro-deoxyuridine monophosphate (FdUMP), which permanently bound to thymidylate synthase. This inhibits the enzyme thymidylate synthase, preventing the methylation of deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP) to deoxythymidine monophosphate (dTMP). As a result, thymidine is not synthesized, halting DNA synthesis, which is particularly lethal to rapidly dividing cancer cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase: This is the mechanism of action of drugs like methotrexate, not 5-FU. Dihydrofolate reductase inhibitors block the formation of tetrahydrofolate, essential for nucleotide synthesis.

 

Option C. Availability of AMP is reduced: This is not a recognized mechanism of action for 5-FU. 5-FU primarily affects thymidine synthesis rather than adenosine monophosphate (AMP).

 

Option D. Causing cross-linkage between adjacent bases of the double helix: This describes the mechanism of action of alkylating agents like cyclophosphamide, not 5-FU. Alkylating agents cause cross-links in DNA, leading to strand breaks and cell death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) is an antimetabolite that acts primarily by inhibiting thymidylate synthase, resulting in decreased thymidine synthesis and subsequent DNA synthesis inhibition. This mechanism makes it effective against rapidly dividing cells, such as those in colorectal adenocarcinoma. 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 717.
